results.title: Always a farmer
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Not just a farmer’s wife, Jenny Grigg, mother of four and business partner in all ways with her husband on their Mallee sheep and grain farm discovered a group of women who were to change Jenny’s life forever.
This story is dedicated to that network of women (PinG) who help and support other farming women in grains by providing inspiration and encouragement and a feeling of self-worth.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.credit_line: Video excerpt and still images on this page are provided courtesy of the artist.
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Green Fingers: Drainage
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Drainage’, gardener Rod Cantrill describes the importance of well-drained soil in the home garden. Cantrill demonstrates how to lay agricultural drainage pipes to remove excess water from the soil, and how to raise garden beds as an alternative method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description:
Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.

The work contains imagery of people who have all shared the same blood. The blood of the Gamilaroi people of Northern NSW.

results.title: Tech Talk. Episodes 19 & 20.
results.creator_credit: Allenog Pty Ltd, Channel 0\28 and John Kyle
results.brief_description: A compilation tape containing eight programmes designed to help young people in their carrer choices. There is also a segment on survival skills. Presented by Michael Shildberger, the topics covered are as follows:- surveyor, spray painter, painter and decorator, being out of work-the parents angle, computers - working in the industry, computers - the new age, florist and how to keep that job.

results.title: In the beginning
results.brief_description: A colourful clay animation film which satirizes society and its impulse to invent nuclear weapons which cause self-destruction. Looks at the invention of destructive weapons from raspberries to rockets! Narration: Brian Woods. Animation: Mark D’Arcy-Irvine, Masfufah Sani. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Walk softly: minimal impact bushwalking
results.brief_description: The rise in popularity of outdoor recreation has led to a vast increase in the number of bushwalkers visiting national parks and wilderness areas. With this rise in use has come increasing damage to the natural environment. Fortunately, a new bushwalking ethic has developed and the “Minimal Impact Bushwalking” philosophy is now widely adopted by bushwalkers. This program covers the major Minimal Impact Bushwalking techniques.
